title: Al-Butaymat
text:
Al-Butaymat (, "El Buteimât") was a <a href="Palestinian%20people">Palestinian Arab</a> village the <a href="Haifa%20Subdistrict%2C%20Mandatory%20Palestine">Haifa Subdistrict</a>, located southeast of <a href="Haifa">Haifa</a>. It was depopulated during the <a href="1947%E2%80%9348%20Civil%20War%20in%20Mandatory%20Palestine">1947–48 Civil War in Mandatory Palestine</a> on May 1, 1948, under the <a href="Battle%20of%20Mishmar%20HaEmek">Battle of Mishmar HaEmek</a>.
History.
In 1882, the <a href="Palestine%20Exploration%20Fund">PEF</a>'s "<a href="PEF%20Survey%20of%20Palestine">Survey of Western Palestine</a>" (SWP) found "traces of ruins" here.
A Haifa man, named Mustafa al-Khalil acquired land in among other places, Al-Butaymat, in the late Ottoman era.
British Mandate era.
In the <a href="1922%20census%20of%20Palestine">1922 census of Palestine</a> conducted by the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">British Mandate authorities</a>, ‘’Al Buteimat’’ had a population 137, all Muslims, decreasing in the <a href="1931%20census%20of%20Palestine">1931 census</a> to 112 Muslims, in a total of 29 houses.
In the <a href="Village%20Statistics%2C%201945">1945 statistics</a> the village had a population of 110 Muslims, and they had 3,832 <a href="dunam">dunam</a>s of land according to an official land and population survey. Of this, 8 dunams were for plantations and irrigable land, 2,508 for cereals, while 4 dunams were built-up (urban) land.
In 1945 the <a href="kibbutz">kibbutz</a> of <a href="Gal%27ed">Gal'ed</a> was established on what was traditionally village land.
1948 and aftermath.
<a href="Benny%20Morris">Benny Morris</a> gives May 1948 as depopulation date, and "Fear of being caught up in the fighting" as the cause, but with a question mark.
In 1992 the village site was described: "The site is fenced in, overgrown with grass and cactuses. There are no traces of houses except for adobe bricks scattered around the site. Most of the surrounding lands are used as grazing areas, but some of them are cultivated."
